data.title: Discussing PrEP Use With Partners
data.introduction: Bring about positive changes in your relationship through better communication

counselling_module_sections.title: How to tell your partner, or someone else you trust, about PrEP…
counselling_module_sections.introduction: It can sometimes be difficult to bring up the issue of HIV prevention with a partner, but there are ways it can become easier.

accordion_content.title: Where to tell someone
accordion_content.description:
• Do it in a comfortable and private place where no one will overhear you and where you will not be interrupted.
  • If you are worried that he may be violent or you are not sure how he will react, don’t be too far away from others so that you can get help if you need it.
  • When to tell someone
  • When you will have enough time to say everything you need to say
  • When you will have enough time for that person to respond and ask questions
  • When both of you are in a good mood and with a settled mind
  • If you are worried that he may become violent, it may help to disclose during the daytime so you can get help more easily, if you need it.

accordion_content.title: Here are some tips you can use to make it easier:
accordion_content.description:
• How to tell someone
  • Use clear and simple language.
  • Maintain eye contact, remain confident and calm.
  • Have prepared answers for anticipated questions
  • Start disclosure indirectly by creating a story talking about PrEP in general without telling him you’re using it and see what he says. If he says negative things, you may not want to tell him you are using it. Gauge his reaction; if you feel he may harm you, do not disclose.
  • Be prepared to answer his questions.
  • Listen openly to your partner’s concerns do not assume you already know what he is going to say.
  • Avoid blaming others when disclosing, especially him. In other words, don’t say that it is his fault that you are using PrEP, because of his behaviours. Instead, say it is your decision to protect yourself.
  • Observe or Look at your partner’s the body language of your partner as you are disclosing or talking to him about PrEP to see his reaction.
  • Be sensitive to emotions and feelings of your partner as you are disclosing or talking to him.

counselling_module_sections.title: What if my partner, or loved one, has a bad reaction?
counselling_module_sections.introduction:
Many people do have misconceptions about PrEP so it’s important to be ready with your response.
Let’s talk about some potential ways your partner, or someone else you tell, might respond if you
told them about PrEP. It can be helpful if you have someone in your life to support you, but not
everyone reacts positively. Remember, it’s your choice whether to talk about your PrEP use, or not.
However, it can be helpful if you have someone in your life to support you.

counselling_module_sections.title: How to use PrEP without anyone knowing
counselling_module_sections.introduction:
Sometimes it makes sense not to tell your partner, or anyone else about your PrEP use, if you think
they’ll be violent towards you or have another reaction that would be hard to handle. If you don’t
want to tell them, that’s your choice, but it’s good to think about how to keep your PrEP use a
secret.

accordion_content.title: Here are some tips that other young women have used:
accordion_content.description:
• Store pills in places your partner, or loved ones will not look, such as a handbag, a keychain with storage, or with pads and tampons.
  • Ask a neighbour or a nearby friend to keep the pills, although this can make it challenging to remember to take them every day.
  • Store a few doses in an unmarked container (ensure that this container is not clear plastic because sun can damage medication).
  • If your partner or loved one monitors or watches you closely, think of a reason for the regular clinic visits. For e.g. you could tell them you’re going to the clinic for a medical condition. You can also tell them you’re taking this medication for another reason such as pregnancy prevention or menstrual cramps.

counselling_module_sections.title: Should I tell my partner, or someone else I love, I’m taking PrEP?
counselling_module_sections.introduction:
There are many things that other women like you think about when deciding whether to tell reasons
that women do and don’t tell their partners, or someone they love, about their use of oral PrEP. It can
be helpful for some young women to have their partner’s support, but it’s important to think about
your own reasons for telling them. What are some reasons that you might want to tell your partner,
or someone you love, about PrEP?
counselling_module_sections.summary:
Remember, whether you share or not is optional. It’s your decision whether to talk to your partner,
or someone else, about PrEP use.

Do you think it would be helpful to tell your partner, or someone else, that you’re using PrEP?
● How do you think they would react?
● Why did or would you tell him?
● Why didn’t or wouldn’t you tell him?

accordion_content.title: Some common reasons for sharing are:
accordion_content.description:
• You feel like you need your partner’s, or someone’s, permission to take PrEP
  • You like to make decisions with your partner, because you ‘share everything’
  • You want their support and encouragement for your decision to use PrEP
  • You think someone can help your adherence by helping you remember to take PrEP successfully, by reminding you to take your daily pill and get refills when needed
  • You worry your partner, or someone else, would be more upset if they found out you were using PrEP without her telling them
  • You don’t want your partner to have misconceptions or misunderstandings about oral PrEP (e.g. Such as think they’re it’s using a muti or ARVs for HIV-positive people)

accordion_content.title: On the other hand, some reasons for NOT sharing include:
accordion_content.description:
• You worry your partner, or someone else you tell, may not allow you to use PrEP or force you to stop using it
  • You worry they may not be supportive, and will think you don’t trust them
  • You worry that your partner may think you are sleeping around and that they will not trust you
  • Your partner might think that PrEP is ARVs, and that you are actually HIV positive
  • You worry your partner may start or continue sleeping around because he thinks you’re protected or he’s protected by your PrEP use
  • You worry your partner may be violen
  • You fear your partner may end the relationship or you’ll be kicked out of your home
  • You don’t feel the need to share the decision with your partner or anyone else. It’s your own body and your decision

counselling_module_action_points.title: Make a decision about whether to tell my partner about PrEP or not
Practice how I’ll respond to my partner’s concerns about PrEP
Prepare for telling my partner (e.g. decide where and when I’ll do it)
Share materials from this site with my partner
Call a PrEP clinic to ask about partner counselling
Make a plan to keep my PrEP secret (e.g. where to store it and when to take it)
